entities.name: PILTDOWN MAN
entities.description: A famous hoax involving a supposed missing link between humans and apes, discovered in England in 1912 and revealed as a forgery in 1953

entities.name: CARDIFF GIANT
entities.description: A hoax involving a 10-foot-tall petrified man "discovered" in Cardiff, New York, in 1869, later revealed to be a sculpture by George Hull

entities.name: WAR OF THE WORLDS BROADCAST
entities.description: A radio broadcast by Orson Welles in 1938 that presented a fictional Martian invasion as real news, causing widespread panic

entities.name: HAN VAN MEEGEREN
entities.description: A Dutch forger who created and sold fake Vermeer paintings during the 1930s and 1940s, fooling art experts and collectors

entities.name: SOKAL AFFAIR
entities.description: A hoax in 1996 where physicist Alan Sokal submitted a fake paper to the journal Social Text, exposing the lack of scientific rigor in postmodernist academic discourse

entities.name: GEORGE HULL
entities.description: The creator of the Cardiff Giant hoax, who sought to profit from public fascination with archaeology and giant mythologies

entities.name: ORSON WELLES
entities.description: An American filmmaker and actor who directed the War of the Worlds radio broadcast in 1938, causing mass hysteria

entities.name: ALAN SOKAL
entities.description: A physicist who exposed the shortcomings of postmodernist academic discourse through the Sokal Affair in 1996

entities.name: HERMANN GÖRING
entities.description: A Nazi leader who purchased one of Han van Meegeren's fake Vermeer paintings
